articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†TypeScript Origins: The Documentary
articles.description: You know you‚Äôve made it when you get your own documentary! This has just dropped but is well produced, packed with stories from TypeScript‚Äôs co-creators, users, and other folks at Microsoft, and kept me entertained. It goes particularly deep into the motivations and process behind TypeScript's creation, including why Microsoft felt it was worth pursuing at all.
articles.author: OfferZen Origins

articles.title: Patterns for Reactivity with Modern Vanilla JavaScript
articles.description: When data changes, you often want to do things, and the process that makes that happen is reactivity. While many libraries or frameworks like React or Vue offer reactive solutions out of the box, you can do it all with vanilla JavaScript too, and this post digs into many of the patterns you might need to use, complete with examples.
articles.author: Marc Grabanski

articles.title: Deno 1.37: Modern JavaScript in Jupyter Notebooks
articles.description: Not content to let Bun take all the headlines, Deno has come up with something pretty neat here. Deno 1.37 ships with a Jupyter Notebook integration so you can create interactive REPL sessions but using the JavaScript you know and love, rather than Python.
articles.author: The Deno Team

articles.title: JavaScript Minification Benchmarks
articles.description: A frequently updated benchmark suite and results comparing the speed and quality of JavaScript minification across a variety of tools including esbuild, Babel, Bun, SWC, and Uglify.
articles.author: Hiroki Osame

articles.title: Getting Network Activity Under Control with Priority Hints
articles.description: A look at how browsers can prioritize the loading of resources, how you can explicitly specify a priority when using fetch, and how different ways of loading scripts are prioritized.
articles.author: Alex MacArthur

articles.title: Securing Node Apps by Analyzing Real Command Injection Examples
articles.description: When code can be manipulated to run unintended, arbitrary commands, it's never going to end well.
articles.author: Liran Tal

articles.title: üß≠ ¬†What's New in Safari 17
articles.description: Safari 17 is now in beta on iOS 17 with the final release dropping across all of Apple‚Äôs platforms next week. On the JavaScript front, Safari and WebKit now fully support the Storage API, WebGL in Offscreen Canvas, v flag support on regexes, Set operation methods, URL.canParse, plus the much anticipated support for PWAs in macOS Sonoma.
articles.author: Jen Simmons and the WebKit team

articles.title: fx 30: The Go(lang)-Powered Terminal JSON¬†Viewer
articles.description: Yes, it's written in Go, but fx has long been a useful tool for looking at JSON files, and it has just been rewritten from the ground up with a new look, regex search, fuzzy search, and support for ‚Äúeven the most massive JSON files.‚Äù You don't need to worry about Go at all; it's simply a fantastic tool for looking at JSON.
articles.author: Anton Medvedev

articles.title: Mantine 7.0: The Popular React Component Library
articles.description: A big release for what is now one of the most popular React component libraries. As of v7, Mantine no longer relies on Emotion and components come with native CSS files, all components now support the system-set color scheme, CSS modules are now the default way to style components, and there are many smaller enhancements too.
articles.author: Mantine Team

articles.title: Chrono 2.7: A Natural Language Date Parser
articles.description: Give it a string like ‚Äútoday‚Äù, ‚Äúlast Friday‚Äù, ‚Äú2 weeks from now‚Äù, or even an entire date and time, and it‚Äôll come up with a date object to suit.
articles.author: Wanasit Tanakitrungruang

articles.title: Theatre.js 0.7: Motion Design for the Web
articles.description: Can be used both programmatically or via a visual editor to animate objects created with things like Three.js, React Three Fiber, HTML/SVG, or even just tween variable values.
articles.author: Theatre.js Project

articles.title: Swup: A Flexible Page Transition Library for Server-Side Rendered¬†Sites
articles.description: A library that benefits hugely from checking out the demos. v4.4 adds experimental ViewTransition support.
articles.author: Georgy Marchuk

articles.title: Create Chrome Extension: A Scaffolding Tool for Chrome Extensions
articles.description: Similar to create-react-app or Yeoman, this is specifically for starting extension development, with support for several frameworks, HMR, and light/dark modes.
articles.author: Yalda

articles.description: The Svelte team offers a sneak peek at the forthcoming Svelte 5 and introduces the idea of 'runes': "Like every other framework, we've come to the realisation that Knockout was right all along."

Happy 27th birthday to JScript! JScript was a version of JavaScript that Microsoft put into IE 3.0 primarily to avoid trademark issues around the name of JavaScript. No-one cares much about that anymore, despite Oracle still technically holding the JavaScript trademark.
Folks are discussing whether Node.js needs a mascot of its own.
Want to support anyone doing great work on JavaScript projects? You can nominate them for a GitHub Star.
If you rely upon the npm package download counts at all, the daily counts for all packages was zero on September 13 and 14 (example). Why? "This issue remains under investigation," says npm support.
Remix v2 ‚Äì Popular full stack web framework.
Bun 1.0.2 ‚Äì Bugfixes, faster bun --watch, it now uses V8's Date parser, and Fastify apps now work too.
Node.js v20.7 (Current) ‚Äì Multiple --env-files now supported.
Next.js 13.5 ‚Äì Faster, faster, faster.

articles.title: WebKit Features in Safari 17.0
articles.description: Safari 17.0 is now available for both iOS 17 and iPadOS 17, it will arrive on macOS a little later this month. This release is packed, and includes support for the <search> element, the popover attribute, the CSS font-size-adjust property, the Storage API, JPEG XL, and much more. Big release!
articles.author: Jen Simmons and the WebKit team

articles.title: v0: Using AI to Build  Frontend Components?
articles.description: An interesting experiment from Vercel where you submit prompts like ‚Äúa country selection field‚Äù or ‚Äúa contact form‚Äù and it returns copy/paste-able shadcn/ui + Tailwind CSS code. It‚Äôs in ‚Äúprivate alpha‚Äù for now, but you can take a good look at how it works here. A sign of the future?
articles.author: Vercel Labs

articles.title: free-for.dev: A Bumper List of Stuff That's 'Free' for Developers
articles.description: An interesting and extensive list of hosted services or otherwise paid-for products that have free tiers or options for developers. We linked to this a couple of years ago but it has been updated a lot since.
articles.author: R.I.Pienaar

articles.title: A (More) Modern CSS Reset
articles.description: Andy created a modern CSS reset almost four years ago, but it‚Äôs time for an update to, well, keep it modern.
articles.author: Andy Bell

articles.title: Get All That Network Activity Under Control with Priority Hints
articles.description: Alex notes how the browser is pretty good at prioritizing resources requests on its own, but it‚Äôs not perfect. He shows us how priority hints makes it easy to provide explicit instructions, and just what scenarios they‚Äôre most helpful in.
articles.author: Alex MacArthur

articles.title: More CSS Findings from the Threads App
articles.description: Ahmad continues his spelunking into Meta‚Äôs new social network, revealing a few interesting CSS findings from the Threads web app.
articles.author: Ahmad Shadeed

articles.title: Revealing Images¬†with¬†CSS Mask¬†Animations
articles.description: A look at combining various CSS masks to create fancy image hover transitions/reveals. There's lots of visual demos and code examples here.
articles.author: Temani Afif

articles.title: A Beginner‚Äôs Guide to Using Pico CSS
articles.description: An overview of getting started with this slimline framework.
articles.author: David Uzondu

articles.title: MDX Editor 1.0: A Rich Markdown Editor Component
articles.description: Best known for the React Virtuoso virtualized rendering components, Petyo has unveiled a Lexical-powered Markdown editor for React apps that supports code blocks, tables, and more. The live demo shows off most of what you need to see.
articles.author: Petyo Ivanov

articles.title: Nue: An Alternative to React, Vue, and Svelte to Build UIs with Cleaner Code
articles.description: Planned to be part of a full tooling ecosystem similar to Vite, Astro, etc., this library has no hooks, effects, props, or other abstractions and is based on a developer-friendly HTML-based template syntax.
articles.author: nue

articles.title: Plotteus: A JavaScript Library for Data Storytelling
articles.description: Looks to be a powerful solution not just for creating static visualizations (graphs, plots, etc.) but interactive ones that visualize data changes via scrolling, UI controls, or other user interactions.
articles.author: Bartosz Prusinowski

articles.title: Create Chrome Extension: A Scaffolding Tool for Your Next Chrome Extension
articles.description: Similar to create-react-app or Yeoman, this one is specifically for starting extension development, with support for 9+ frameworks, TS/JS, HMR, and light/dark modes.
articles.author: Yalda

articles.description: WordPress blogs can now be followed in the fediverse.
üìÖ CodeWord is an upcoming free online event (tomorrow) looking at how developers interact with content in their code. Speakers include Chris Coyier, Cassisy Williams, Miriam Schwab, and others.
Browser company Vivaldi has penned an open letter to the EU Commission to express "concerns over Microsoft‚Äôs anti-competitive practices" in regards to Edge.
Figma-friendly design tool Anima now has Tailwind CSS support.
‚ôñ Opera is releasing a 'special edition' of their browser, with built-in.. chess?
